author: VitalikButerin
text:
Check out the deep funding round here!

https://t.co/Dwr8po574S

author: VitalikButerin
text:
Deep funding does this for a multi-level graph: what deserves how much credit for what? If you come up with good-enough values for edges of such a graph, then you can fund a single node, and funds will automatically flow to all dependencies.

Could be used as a form of issuance. https://t.co/MRALDP1dOv

author: VitalikButerin
text: Another is distilled human judgement: AIs (or human+AI hybrids) answer a big list of questions, humans answer a randomly chosen much smaller set https://t.co/8wg9YM5Okj

author: VitalikButerin
text: One example of this is futarchy https://t.co/wAXQP3bReH

author: VitalikButerin
text: An alternative is to create an open-access game, where humans are acting as referees in the game, and AIs are the players. https://t.co/XAS9wJMsJR

author: VitalikButerin
text: One naive way to use AI in onchain DAOs and other mechanisms is to just put a single AI in charge. But this has a lot of problems: https://t.co/E6cdSjmU5j

author: VitalikButerin
text:
AI as the engine, humans as the steering wheel:

https://t.co/5Hrlkw9v6v

author: VitalikButerin
text:
Reminder: there's also plenty of people who have lost huge amounts of crypto to *loss* rather than theft.

Software bug, forgotten password, lost device, paper wallet burned down in LA fire, upgraded device without backing up data .... lots of ways for that to happen.

Because

author: VitalikButerin
text:
@AISafetyMemes correction: "... even if you think the specific animal in question is probably not conscious ..."

Didn't mean to claim that this is true for non-human animals in general

author: VitalikButerin
text:
@AISafetyMemes I was polite to NPCs in World of Warcraft.

It's the same rationale as why you want to not be cruel to animals even if they're probably not conscious: you don't want to strengthen the pathways in your brain that are ok with that sort of thing.

author: VitalikButerin
VitalikButerin
text:
@robertwiblin @fchollet ?

At least I think he has some of the most detailed models of why there might be entire categories of thinking (rather than just degrees of capability) that present-day AI is missing that humans have and true general-purpose AI needs.

author: VitalikButerin
text:
@alpeh_v @yush_g The good news is that the specific choice of hash function is very easy to replace at any point up until the actual hard fork that swaps the tree (and beacon chain and...)

So we want to have as much progress and information as possible on different options by ~2027

text:

author: VitalikButerin
text:
@ReiSoleilJr @FUCORY The proof format is `bytes`

That part is actually the easy part. It's up to each individual L2's proof verification EVM function to interpret those bytes.

author: VitalikButerin
text:
@FUCORY My preferred approach is an ERC similar to https://t.co/RwYNOuuEUM by which L2s can declare an onchain config contract that specifies how to verify state proofs (as a piece of EVM code)

So you can write a universal L2 light client that asks for proofs over a p2p network and then

How it works:

author: VitalikButerin
text: @singularityhack @evabeylin @owocki @ameensol yes, this is indeed one of the most common definitions used by proponentsüòä

author: VitalikButerin
text:
@evabeylin @owocki @ameensol to me, capitalism is not just about the role of markets, it's also about the role of property rights and capital accumulation, and the absence of a role for certain forms of large-scale coordination for objectives that go beyond maintenance of a property rights system

also, a

author: VitalikButerin
text:
@evabeylin @owocki @ameensol I recently have been feeling like actually defining "capitalism" is one of those topics worthy of a long long blog post...

The more you observe the more it's very clear that the definitions used by self-described proponents and critics of capitalism are *very* different

author: VitalikButerin
text:
@owocki @ameensol make communism great again

Milady

author: VitalikButerin
VitalikButerin
text:
QR codes are good though.

My main beef with them is that I think the QR code should just contain the menu directly, skip the URL step. No more agonizing long waits for the thing to load.

Max QR code size is 2953 bytes, plenty to fit a text menu, with modern gen-AI compression

author: VitalikButerin
text: @CharlotteFang77 I agree that hate speech is basically a no-op when it's a few randos without institutional support. It's only really harmful when the elites themselves are in on it - and this is the fundamental reason why top-down censorship doesn't work at its stated goals: it's only dangerous

author: VitalikButerin
text: @CharlotteFang77 I don't think intent matters that much when we're evaluating the extent to which that kind of rhetoric accelerates the slippery slope toward darkness. The avant garde thinks they're joking, but then the next cohort thinks that it's real, and slowly things escalate and the
